people.name: St. Peter
people.summary: Simon Peter, also known as Cephas, was one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus Christ and the first Bishop of Rome (Pope). He is traditionally considered the leader of the apostles and the foundation of the Church. According to tradition, he was martyred in Rome by crucifixion, upside down at his own request.
keyQuotes: You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.
Lord, to whom shall we go? You have the words of eternal life.

people.name: St. Paul

locations.description: Conversion on the road to Damascus

people.summary: Paul the Apostle, originally known as Saul of Tarsus, was a major figure in the spread of Christianity throughout the Roman Empire. After his dramatic conversion on the road to Damascus, he became the 'Apostle to the Gentiles' and wrote many of the New Testament epistles. He was martyred in Rome by beheading.
keyQuotes: I have been crucified with Christ. It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me.
For I am convinced that neither death nor life... will be able to separate us from the love of God.

people.name: St. Stephen
people.summary: Stephen was one of the first seven deacons chosen by the apostles to serve the early Christian community in Jerusalem. He is venerated as the first Christian martyr, stoned to death for his faith. His martyrdom is recorded in the Acts of the Apostles, and his dying words echo those of Christ on the cross.
keyQuotes: Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.
Lord, do not hold this sin against them.

people.name: St. James the Great
people.summary: James, son of Zebedee, was one of the Twelve Apostles and the brother of John the Evangelist. He was the first apostle to be martyred, beheaded by King Herod Agrippa I in Jerusalem around 44 AD. He is the patron saint of Spain, where his remains are said to be enshrined in Santiago de Compostela.

people.name: St. Mark the Evangelist

locations.description: Founder and first Bishop of Alexandria

people.summary: Mark the Evangelist is traditionally credited with writing the Gospel of Mark, the earliest of the four canonical gospels. He is also considered the founder of the Church of Alexandria and its first bishop. According to tradition, he was martyred in Alexandria.

people.name: St. Barnabas
people.summary: Barnabas was an early Christian disciple and missionary companion of Paul the Apostle. He was instrumental in introducing Paul to the apostles in Jerusalem and later accompanied him on missionary journeys. He is considered an apostle and is traditionally said to have been martyred in Cyprus.

people.name: St. Luke the Evangelist
people.summary: Luke the Evangelist is traditionally credited with writing the Gospel of Luke and the Acts of the Apostles. He was a physician and a companion of Paul the Apostle on his missionary journeys. His gospel emphasizes the universal nature of Christ's mission and includes many details about women and the poor.

people.name: St. John the Evangelist
people.summary: John the Evangelist, also known as John the Beloved Disciple, was one of the Twelve Apostles and the author of the Gospel of John, three epistles, and the Book of Revelation. He was the only apostle not to be martyred, living to an old age in Ephesus. He is traditionally identified as the 'disciple whom Jesus loved.'
keyQuotes: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
God is love, and whoever abides in love abides in God, and God abides in him.

people.name: St. Clement of Rome

locations.description: Third or fourth Bishop of Rome

people.summary: Clement of Rome, also known as Pope Clement I, was one of the Apostolic Fathers and an early bishop of Rome. He is best known for his First Epistle to the Corinthians, one of the earliest Christian documents outside the New Testament. According to tradition, he was martyred by being tied to an anchor and thrown into the sea.
keyQuotes: Let us be humble, therefore, brethren, laying aside all arrogance and conceit and folly and anger.

people.name: St. Ignatius of Antioch
people.summary: Ignatius of Antioch was an early Christian writer and bishop of Antioch. He was martyred in Rome, and on his way there, he wrote seven letters to various churches. These letters are among the earliest Christian documents outside the New Testament.
keyQuotes: Where the bishop is, there let the multitude of believers be; even as where Jesus is, there is the Catholic Church.
I am God's wheat, and I shall be ground by the teeth of wild beasts, that I may be found the pure bread of Christ.

people.name: St. Polycarp
people.summary: Polycarp was a 2nd-century Christian bishop of Smyrna. According to the Martyrdom of Polycarp, he was martyred by being stabbed after an attempt to burn him at the stake proved unsuccessful.
keyQuotes: Eighty and six years have I served Christ, and He never did me any injury: how then can I blaspheme my King and my Saviour?

people.name: St. Irenaeus
people.summary: Irenaeus was a Greek bishop noted for his role in guiding and expanding Christian communities in the southern regions of present-day France and, more widely, for the development of Christian theology by combating heresy and defining orthodoxy.
keyQuotes: The glory of God is man fully alive, and the life of man is the vision of God.

people.name: St. Athanasius
people.summary: Athanasius was a Christian theologian, bishop of Alexandria, and a noted Egyptian leader of the fourth century. He is best known for his role in the conflict with Arius and Arianism. At the First Council of Nicaea, Athanasius argued against the Arians and was a key defender of the doctrine of the Trinity.
keyQuotes: For the Son of God became man so that we might become God.
He, indeed, assumed humanity that we might become God.

people.name: St. Basil the Great
people.summary: Basil of Caesarea, also called Saint Basil the Great, was a bishop of Caesarea Mazaca in Cappadocia, Asia Minor. He was an influential theologian who supported the Nicene Creed and opposed the heresies of the early Christian church.
keyQuotes: The bread which you do not use is the bread of the hungry; the garment hanging in your wardrobe is the garment of him who is naked.

people.name: St. Gregory of Nazianzus
people.summary: Gregory of Nazianzus, also known as Gregory the Theologian or Gregory Nazianzen, was a 4th-century Archbishop of Constantinople, and theologian. He is widely considered the most accomplished rhetorical stylist of the patristic age.
keyQuotes: What is not assumed is not healed.

people.name: St. Ambrose
people.summary: Ambrose was a bishop of Milan who became one of the most influential ecclesiastical figures of the 4th century. He is counted as one of the four original doctors of the Church.
keyQuotes: When in Rome, do as the Romans do.

people.name: St. John Chrysostom
people.summary: John Chrysostom was an important Early Church Father who served as archbishop of Constantinople. He is known for his preaching and public speaking, his denunciation of abuse of authority by both ecclesiastical and political leaders, and his Divine Liturgy.
keyQuotes: The rich man is not one who is in possession of much, but one who gives much.

people.name: St. Augustine of Hippo
people.summary: Augustine of Hippo, also known as Saint Augustine, was a theologian and philosopher of Berber origin and the bishop of Hippo Regius in Numidia, Roman North Africa. His writings influenced the development of Western philosophy and Western Christianity.
keyQuotes: You have made us for yourself, O Lord, and our hearts are restless until they rest in you.
Late have I loved you, O Beauty ever ancient, ever new, late have I loved you!

people.name: Arius
people.summary: Arius was a Cyrenaic presbyter, ascetic, and priest in Alexandria, Egypt. His teachings about the nature of the Godhead, which emphasized the Father's divinity over the Son, and his opposition to what would become the Nicene Creed, made him a primary topic of the First Council of Nicaea.
keyQuotes: There was a time when the Son was not.

events.name: Council of Jerusalem
events.summary: The Council of Jerusalem was the first Christian council, held around 50 AD to address the question of whether Gentile converts to Christianity needed to follow Jewish law, particularly circumcision. The council, led by James the Just and attended by Peter and Paul, decided that Gentile converts did not need to be circumcised, establishing the universal nature of the Christian mission.

events.name: Martyrdom of St. Stephen
events.summary: St. Stephen became the first Christian martyr when he was stoned to death in Jerusalem around 34 AD. His martyrdom marked the beginning of the first persecution of Christians and led to the scattering of believers throughout Judea and Samaria, which paradoxically helped spread the faith.

events.name: Martyrdom of St. James the Great
events.summary: St. James the Great, one of the Twelve Apostles and brother of John the Evangelist, became the first apostle to be martyred when he was beheaded by King Herod Agrippa I in Jerusalem around 44 AD. This marked the beginning of a new wave of persecution against the early Church.

events.name: Nero's Persecution of Christians
events.summary: Following the Great Fire of Rome in 64 AD, Emperor Nero blamed Christians for the disaster and initiated the first systematic persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire. This persecution resulted in the martyrdoms of St. Peter and St. Paul, among many others. Christians were tortured, crucified, and burned alive as human torches.

events.name: Martyrdom of St. Peter and St. Paul
events.summary: St. Peter and St. Paul were both martyred in Rome during Nero's persecution. According to tradition, Peter was crucified upside down at his own request around 64 AD, while Paul was beheaded around 67 AD. Their martyrdoms marked a turning point in early Church history, establishing Rome as a center of Christian martyrdom and authority.

events.name: Destruction of Jerusalem
events.summary: In 70 AD, the Roman general Titus besieged and destroyed Jerusalem, including the Second Temple, in response to the First Jewish-Roman War. This event fulfilled Jesus' prophecy about the destruction of the Temple and marked the end of the Jewish-Christian center in Jerusalem, forcing the Church to spread throughout the Roman Empire.

events.name: First Council of Nicaea
events.summary: The First Council of Nicaea was a council of Christian bishops convened in the Bithynian city of Nicaea by the Roman Emperor Constantine I in AD 325. This ecumenical council was the first effort to attain consensus in the church through an assembly representing all of Christendom.

events.name: First Council of Constantinople
events.summary: The First Council of Constantinople was a council of Christian bishops convened in Constantinople in AD 381 by the Roman Emperor Theodosius I. This second ecumenical council, a continuation of the First Council of Nicaea, was intended to complete the Nicene Creed.

events.name: Council of Ephesus
events.summary: The Council of Ephesus was a council of Christian bishops convened in Ephesus in AD 431 by the Roman Emperor Theodosius II. This third ecumenical council, an effort to attain consensus in the church, confirmed the original Nicene Creed, and condemned the teachings of Nestorius.

events.name: Council of Chalcedon
events.summary: The Council of Chalcedon was a church council held from 8 October to 1 November 451, at Chalcedon, a town of Bithynia in Asia Minor. The council was attended by over 520 bishops or their representatives, making it the largest and best-documented of the first seven ecumenical councils.
